guide.title: Using Emacs XFT Support
guide.abstract: This document shows you how to enable and use antialiased (pretty) fonts for Emacs.

body.note: Font anti-aliasing using the Xft library and FreeType fonts is currently only available for the app-editors/emacs-cvs-23.0.0_p20070920 and app-editors/emacs-cvs-23.0.60 ebuilds.
body.p: You'll need to first unmask and keyword the emacs-cvs-23 ebuild -- it's experimental and potentially unstable.
Next, set the appropriate USE flags - you must have the xft flag.
Now it's time to install the CVS version of emacs:
You can now use XFT fonts in emacs; try emerging ttf-bitstream-vera first.
If you're happy with this as your default font, set it in your ~/.Xresources:

pre.caption: Setting the default font for emacs startup

body.pre: $ echo "Emacs.font: Bitstream Vera Sans Mono-12" >> ~/.Xresources $ xrdb -merge ~/.Xresources
body.p: The emacs-cvs-23 branch is (currently) considered too unstable for production use; if you experience problems you may want to have a stable-but-not-antialiased version available as a standby. You can use eselect to switch between the various emacs versions installed on your system.
body.pre:
(Check available versions) $ eselect emacs list Available GNU Emacs symlink targets: [1] emacs-21 [2] emacs-22 [3] emacs-23 * [4] emacs-23-unicode
XEmacs is also installed (Select the correct version) # eselect emacs set emacs-23-unicode
